div.p:
It is long since I have felt so much
satisfaction as I felt this morning
from your letter. Both Mrs. Edgeworth
my aunts and I thought we might feel sure
that of what your opinion would
be, but to have that opinion so fully
and clearly expressed, to see the
reasons by which it is supported
so ably stated & to feel at once that
they are perfectly solid and that
they entirely coincide with my own
is highly satisfactory to me - I told
you truly, that I was conscious that
I should not have been able to act
in consequence of your opinion
had it been contrary to my own
- that no power but that which can
never more be exerted over my mind
could even if I were convinced it
were right & necessary excite
me at this time to such an attempt
- But the more I felt that your opinion
had it been on the other side of the question
would have been inadequate to rouse
me to exertion above my powers
the more I felt anxious that such
should not be the opinion of the
friend whose judgment I know my
dear father valued above that of any
other of his friends and upon whose
personal attachment, knowledge of
his character and regard for his me-
-mory memory he relied more than upon
those of any other man living - ex
-cept except his own sons -
I thank you particularly for stating
all your reasons distinctly as your
own, without reference to my sentiments.
- I shall have to consult you probably
hereafter on many points - and so
once for all, be assured that you can
never speak the truth to me too flatly
or too strongly - Consider I have been
used to it - and used to feel it the surest
proof of friendship -

You have relieved me from all
remaining fear scruple of dis-obeying that
injunction with which I never promised
to comply - which it was dreadful to me
to hear- and to recollect - still more dreadful.
- I am glad that you coolly & at a distance
agree with Mrs. E and me that it was a feverish
feeling
which dictated that letter to Hunter - How
I rejoice that I did not send it - and
yet at the time I feared I was doing wrong

But as you say dear Francis I
must not ever more permit myself to
think of that injunction - I must emulate
"his strength of resolution which rejected
"all minor views incompatible with
"a great object. - How kind of you to say
that "Could he now look down upon
"the struggles of my heart he would
"cheer me on & encourage me to do that
"which in my conscience I judge most fit"

It seems as if you had looked
straight to the bottom of my heart for
this is the idea the question that
perpetually reccurs to me
"If he could look down upon
"me - could see me now what would
"he think - would he approve or disap-
"-prove disprove .? -
On the question touched upon in the
conclusion of your letter - should the
Memoirs be in his own person & as
written by him? - I differ from you- - But
we shall have time & time enough to
discuss this hereafter - we differ only
because you do not know the facts - and
have not seen the Ms
messages - Mrs. E has read
it all and agrees with me - I had never
had the courage to read open it till two days
ago when I felt the propriety the necessity
of my two aunts seeing it & of hearing their
opinion on the points that peculiarly concern
their family before they should leave us -
I could not send the Ms. messages to them - Their
eyes are both so bad that they could not
read the Ms. messages to themselves - There was
no alternative - I had the resolution to
begin to read it to them myself - An hour
every day they are to come to my room -
for this purpose - The first hour you may
conceive touched us exceedingly - But
it was satisfactory to us all - When
you see the Ms. which you certainly shall
see, your judgment will, I can almost
venture to say I am certain, agree
with ours - as far as we have gone -
- As to the main point that it should be
his own I have no doubt - If I find
any thing that I think or that you think
right to be omitted I will omit
expunge
but I will not alter a word any passage
or change any sentiment - that I should
think a dereliction of my duty & breaking
a sacred trust -

But I will restrain myself from en-
tering entering more into a question which we
shall have time hereafter I hope to discuss
I entirely agree (I scarcely need say) I
agree with you as to the time of publication
- Thank God - you think so

I employ myself & have em-
ployed employed myself unremittingly for some
hours every morning since I returned
home in reading over his incomparable
letters on public subjects & those of Mr. Day which he had permiss-
ion permission to publish & I have expunged all
passages
that ought to be expunged & marked such
of the very few letters as I think fit to be
used - I have written my opinion on
each & arranged them so that if I were
to die before I could com fulfil the trust
reposed in me, at least I shall have
done something towards it & all that
I could do -

Before poor Madame de Stael
lost her faculties it must have been
a delightful satisfaction to her that
she had finished her life of her father
- I am in excellent health and
not in the least apprehensive that my
health should fail - on the contrary
I hav felt it strengthen under the
pre which I sh.d
should sometime time ago
have thought would have overwhelmed
it - But tho I am in good health now
human life is so uncertain that I feel
it a an imperious duty in this instance not to procras-
-tinate procrastinate - & all that I can do I will
div.closer:
I am your grateful friend
Maria Edgeworth -
Captain Beaufort
Epping
Essex -
